nodes.text:
- i. The purpose of this process is to create, review, approve, and publish a contract.
- ii. Contract should not be created against Supplier with 'Disqualified' status in the Supplier Master Database, maintained by the DGS.

metadata.context: This chunk describes the "Create contract" activity within the Create and Publish Contract process of the Contract Lifecycle Management (CLM) process group, specifying that the Contracting Specialist/Lead creates a contract based on an approved 'Award Recommendation Report' and that the contract can be a master agreement, sub-agreement, or stand-alone agreement. It appears on Page 43 and is part of the detailed workflow for initiating contract creation in the CLM process.

nodes.text:
- i. Create contract
- a. The assigned Contracting Specialist/Lead creates a contract against an approved 'A ward Recommendation Report' .
- b. The contract could be the master agreement, sub-agreement or stand-alone agreement.

metadata.context: This chunk describes the review and approval process for a completed contract as per the PDoA, occurring after the contract is created and before it is signed and published, as outlined on Page 43.

nodes.text:
- a. Completed contract is reviewed by reviewers designated as per the PDoA .
- b. Reviewed contract is approved by approvers designated as per the PDoA .

metadata.context: This chunk describes the post-approval actions for a contract, including obtaining signed copies from the Supplier and internal stakeholders, sharing the signed contract, and initiating supplier performance evaluation—aligning with the contract publication and management process on Page 43.

nodes.text:
- a. The assigned Contracting Specialist/Lead obtains signatures on two copies of the approved contract from authorized signatories, starting with the Supplier. One copy is shared with the Supplier while the other hard copy is retained by the Procurement .
- b. Signed contract is shared with relevant internal stakeholders.
- c. The  assigned Contracting  Specialist/Lead initiates  procedures  to  evaluate  and  manage Supplier performance  against  each  contract.  These  procedures  are  detailed  in Section 2.5.2.(III).

metadata.context: This chunk describes the types and nature of contract amendments within the contract lifecycle, specifically outlining that amendments can be administrative, substantive, or involve renewal/extension, and that the original contract remains valid while changes are documented and implemented. It is situated on Page 43 of the document, following the contract creation and publication process, and precedes a detailed table of amendment types on Page 44.

headings: Table 2.4.1 Roles and Responsibilities -Create and Publish Contract

nodes.text:
- i. Contract amendment allows to make modifications to the existing contract, which have been approved and agreed with the Supplier .
- ii. An amendment may be an addition, deletion, or modification to the existing contract. The original contract remains in place, along with changes made via the amendment.
- iii. Following types of amendments can be made to a contract:

metadata.context: This chunk describes the two types of contract amendments—Administrative and Substantive—as defined in Section 2.4.2 on Page 43 of the document, which outlines the process for creating, reviewing, and approving contract amendments. It is situated within the broader context of contract management and amendment procedures, specifically detailing when and how changes to existing contracts are authorized and implemented.

nodes.text: Administrative Amendment, Details = • Allows for changes that do not affect or alter the rights of the Entity/ Supplier and do not have any financial/material impact (e.g., changes in billing instruction or address, correction of typographical errors, etc.). Substantive Amendment, Details = • Includes modifications such as change orders, change requests, scope modification, price updates.

metadata.context: This chunk defines the types and conditions for contract renewals/extensions, specifying that they require approval by the Contract Administrator, existing contractual provisions, and verified budget availability, and is part of the contract amendment process outlined in Section 2.4.2.(I) on Page 44.

nodes.text:
Table 2.4.2 Types of Contract Amendments

Renewal/ Extension, Details.• Allows for changes in the contract by adding, removing, or modifying the obligations or benefits = • Requested by Contract Administrator • Permitted only if relevant provisions exist in the contract • Procurement must verify that sufficient approved budget is available for Renewal/ Extension before initiating the amendment.

metadata.context: This chunk describes the initial steps in the contract amendment process, specifically how an amendment is raised (by Supplier or Contract Administrator), validated by the Contract Administrator, and evaluated for budget requirements in collaboration with the Budget Owner, forming the starting point for further review and approval as detailed in Section 2.4.2.(II) on Page 44.

nodes.text:
- a. An amendment is raised either by the Supplier or the Contract Administrator . In either case, the Contract  Administrator confirms  the  validity  of  the  amendment.  In  case  there  is  an associated budget requirement, the proposed amendment is reviewed in collaboration with the Budget Owner .
- b. In  case  the  amendment  is  valid,  and  the  budget  availability  is  confirmed,  the Contract Administrator communicates the amendment  details to the assigned Contracting Specialist/Lead .
- c. If the amendment is invalid, it is communicated to respective stakeholders, and any relevant query is resolved.

metadata.context: This chunk describes the actions taken by the Contracting Specialist/Lead when handling different types of contract amendments—administrative changes, substantive amendments, and renewals/extensions—specifically outlining whether changes are made directly or require formal documentation and approval processes as per the PDoA. It appears on Page 44 and is part of the "Manage Contract Amendments" process.

headings: iii. Review and Approve amended contract

- b. In  case  of  Substantive  amendments  and  Renewal/Extension,  the  assigned Contracting Specialist/Lead creates  contract  amendment  documentation  which  is  reviewed  and approved as per the PDoA .

headings: iii. Review and Approve amended contract

metadata.context: This chunk describes the validation and initial handling of claims/penalties/disputes in contracts, outlining the process where either the Contract Administrator or Supplier raises the issue, the Contract Administrator verifies its validity and checks budget availability (with Budget Owner if needed), communicates valid claims to the Contracting Specialist/Lead, and initiates the logging and approval process. It corresponds to Section 2.4.3 on managing contract claims/penalties/disputes on Page 45 and is part of the broader contract amendment and dispute management process.

nodes.text:
- i. Validate claim/penalty/dispute
- a. Claim/penalty/dispute  is  raised  either  by  the Contract  Administrator or  the Supplier .  In either case, the Contract Administrator confirms the validity of the claim/penalty/dispute. In case there is an associated budget requirement, the claim/penalty/dispute is reviewed in collaboration with the Budget Owner .
- b. In  case  the  claim/penalty/dispute  is  valid,  and  the  budget  availability  is  confirmed,  the Contract Administrator communicates details of the claim/penalty/dispute to the assigned Contracting Specialist/Lead .
- c. If case the claim/penalty/dispute is invalid, it is communicated to respective stakeholders, and any relevant query is resolved.
- d. The assigned Contracting Specialist/Lead completes and submits the 'Claim/Penalty/Dispute Logging Form', along with any supporting document, for reviews and approvals.

metadata.context: This chunk describes the conditions under which a contract can be closed or terminated, as outlined in Section 2.4.2.(III) on Page 47, which details the contract closure and termination process, including expiry, fulfillment of obligations, and voluntary termination.

nodes.text:
- a. The purpose of this process is to close or terminate the contract, under following circumstances:
2. a1. All contractual obligations are met.
3. a2. The contract is expired.
4. a3. The contract is being terminated.

metadata.context: This chunk describes the Contracting Specialist/Lead's responsibilities in monitoring contracts for expiry or closure, handling extensions/renewals (requiring Contract Administrator approval), and proceeding with contract closure if renewal is not requested, including using an approved template for the Contract Closure Checklist. It appears on Page 47 and is part of the process for closing or terminating contracts under Section 2.4.2.(IV).

nodes.text:
- a. The assigned Contracting Specialist/Lead monitors the contract for upcoming expiry and closure.
- b. In  case  the  contract  is  about  to  expire,  while  contractual  obligations  are  pending,  the assigned Contracting Specialist/Lead may extend the contract to allow the Supplier to meet all contractual obligations. Any contract extension/renewal must be requested by Contract Administrator and duly approved.
- c. The process for Extension/Renewal amendment is explained in Section 2.4.2.(II).
- d. In  case  the  contract  is  not  to  be  renewed  or  extended,  the  assigned Contracting Specialist/Lead reviews  the  'Contract  Closure  Checklist',  completes  relevant  activities, collate required documents to close the contract.
- e. The  assigned Contracting  Specialist/Lead may  either  use  the  provided  template  for 'Contract Closure Checklist' or another approved template covering the required elements.

metadata.context: This chunk describes the process for terminating a contract, specifically detailing the steps from raising a termination request by the Contract Administrator to the final approval and issuance of the 'Termination Notice' to the Supplier, as outlined in Section 2.4.2.(IV) on Page 47 of the document.

nodes.text:
- a. Request to terminate contract is raised by the Contract Administrator .
- b. Based  on  the  request,  a  'Termination  Notice'  is  prepared  by  the  assigned Contracting Specialist/Lead in collaboration with the Contract Administrator and the Legal .
- c. Completed 'Termination Notice', along with supporting documents, is reviewed by reviewers designated as per the PDoA .
- d. Reviewed 'Termination Notice', along with supporting documents, is approved by approvers designated as per the PDoA .
- e. Approved 'Termination Notice' is sent to the Supplier .

metadata.context: This chunk outlines the final steps in the contract closure/expiry/termination process, specifically the communication of closure to stakeholders and coordination with Finance for releasing performance bonds or retentions, as detailed in Section 2.4.2.(IV) on Page 47.

nodes.text:
- a. Closure/expiry/termination of the contract is communicated to relevant stakeholders.
- b. The assigned Contracting Specialist/Lead coordinate  with  the Finance for  release  of  the Performance Bond or retentions (as applicable), post-closure/ termination of the contract.

metadata.context: This chunk outlines the responsibilities of the Contracting Specialist/Lead in the contract closure/termination process, specifically on Page 47, as part of the "Close/Terminate Contract" workflow, which follows the steps of monitoring expiry, completing the closure checklist, preparing and sending a termination notice, and communicating closure to stakeholders.

nodes.text: Contracting Specialist/Lead, Responsibilities = 1. Monitor contract for expiry/closure. 2. Review and complete relevant activities in the 'Contract Closure Checklist'. 3. Create 'Termination Notice' in collaboration with the Contract Administrator and the Legal . 4. Send the approved 'Termination Notice' to the Supplier . 5. Communicate contract expiry/closure/termination to the relevant stakeholders.

metadata.context: This chunk introduces the Supplier Performance and Relationship Management (SPRM) process group, outlining its key components—segmenting suppliers, managing relationships, and evaluating supplier performance—within the broader procurement framework. It is located on Page 49 and follows the CLM process group details, providing a transition to supplier-specific management activities.

nodes.text:
- a) Supplier Performance and Relationship Management (SPRM) process group consists of procedures to segment Suppliers , manage relationships with selected Suppliers , and manage performance of Suppliers against open contracts.
- b) This  section  explains  the  activities,  decisions  involved,  documents  used,  outcomes,  and  the stakeholders involved in the SPRM processes.
- c) The following Level 3 processes are included in the SPRM process group:
1. Segment Suppliers
2. Set Relationships with Selected Suppliers
3. Evaluate and Manage Supplier Performance

metadata.context: This chunk describes the "Segment Suppliers" process within the Supplier Performance and Relationship Management (SPRM) process group, detailing supplier classification into strategic, critical, operational, and transactional segments, along with key execution guidelines and responsibilities as outlined on Page 49 of the document.

nodes.text:
- i. The purpose of this process is to classify Suppliers into following pre-defined segments:
- a. Strategic Suppliers -show potential of innovation and collaboration, have a proven track record, and are some of the highest spend Suppliers .
- b. Critical Suppliers -are critical to everyday operations and any failure by such Suppliers has a significant impact on the Entity 's operations.
- c. Operational Suppliers -have contracted commitments that require operational tracking and delivery monitoring .
- d. Transactional Suppliers -have minimal contracted spend with the least impact.
- ii. Common Category Suppliers are considered as Strategic Suppliers .
- iii. Segment Suppliers process is executed periodically, preferably once a year.
- iv. While segmenting Suppliers, it is crucial to consider the contracted spend with each Supplier for the same period to maintain a fair comparison. Only Suppliers with contracted spend during the period of review may be considered for this process.
- v. An SRM Specialist is assigned to segment Suppliers . To segment Suppliers catering to Common Categories, SRM Specialist is assigned from the GPO and to segment Suppliers catering to EntitySpecific Categories, SRM Specialist is assigned from the Entity managing the category.

4. a2. Supplier  Risk  /Complexity  implies  the  dependence  on  the Supplier and  ease  of switching the Supplier , if required.

nodes.text:
- i. The purpose of this process is to evaluate and manage Supplier performance.
- ii. Supplier performance is evaluated and managed against each open contract, separately. Each evaluation leads to a 'Supplier Performance Scorecard', which summarizes performance against the KPIs of the contract.
- iii. The Contracting  Specialist/Lead, assigned  to  execute  the  CLM  processes,  is  responsible  for evaluating and managing Supplier performance against the respective contract.

metadata.context: This chunk describes the process of collecting supplier performance inputs, including customization of the evaluation form, definition of KPIs, communication of criteria, and data collection from contract administrators and end-users, and it is situated on Page 54 within the supplier performance evaluation process that follows contract-specific KPIs and is managed by the Contracting Specialist/Lead.

nodes.text:
- i. Collect Supplier performance inputs
- a. The assigned Contracting Specialist/Lead identifies the frequency of Supplier performance evaluation and customizes the 'Supplier Performance Input Collection Form'.
- b. The provided 'Supplier Performance Input Collection Form' template is designed to evaluate Supplier performance against the following KPIs:
4. b1. Account Management
5. b2. Cost
6. b3. Quality
7. b4. Delivery
8. b5. Innovation
9. b6. Risk and Compliance
- c. The Supplier performance evaluation criteria (weightage, target grade, and questions within each KPI) is decided by the nature of the contract.
- d. Details of Supplier performance evaluation criteria and frequency are communicated to the Supplier.
- e. For each performance evaluation cycle, the assigned Contracting Specialist/Lead shares the 'Supplier  Performance  Evaluation  Form'  with  relevant Contract  Administrators and EndUsers .
- f. Relevant Contract  Administrators and End-Users fill  the 'Supplier  Performance  Input Collection Form' with details of the Supplier performance for the specific period.

metadata.context: This chunk describes the process of collating supplier performance inputs and issuing a Supplier Performance Scorecard, which is part of the supplier performance evaluation cycle on Page 54, following input collection from Contract Administrators and End-Users.

headings: iii. Create and approve 'Supplier Performance Management (SPM) Plan'

nodes.text:
- a. The  assigned Contracting  Specialist/Lead collates  various 'Supplier  Performance  Input Collection Form' and fills the provided 'Supplier Performance Scorecard' template .
- b. The 'Supplier Performance Scorecard' is shared with relevant stakeholders (including the Supplier ) and the performance cycle is considered closed, if the Supplier meets the target grade for all KPIs.

headings: iii. Create and approve 'Supplier Performance Management (SPM) Plan'
metadata.context: This chunk describes the action taken when a supplier fails to meet target grades in performance evaluations, outlining the creation, review, and approval of a Supplier Performance Management Plan as part of the supplier performance management process detailed on Page 55.

nodes.text:
- a. If  the Supplier fails  to  meet  the  target  grades,  the  assigned Contracting  Specialist/Lead cr eates a 'Supplier Performance Management Plan' to rectify Supplier performance.
- b. The assigned Contracting Specialist/Lead may either use the provided template for 'Supplier Performance Management Plan' or another approved template covering required elements.
- c. The completed 'Supplier Performance Management Plan' is reviewed with the Supplier, to finalize and prioritize corrective actions.
- d. Reviewed 'Supplier  Performance  Management  Plan' is  approved  by the approvers designated as per the PDoA .

metadata.context: This chunk describes the post-approval execution and monitoring of the 'Supplier Performance Management Plan', detailing periodic reviews, status updates, modification approvals, and plan completion, as outlined in Section 2.5.2.(III) on Page 55 of the document context.

headings: iii. Create and approve 'Supplier Performance Management (SPM) Plan'

nodes.text:
- a. Approved 'Supplier Performance Management Plan' is shared with relevant stakeholders for execution.
- b. The assigned Contracting Specialist/Lead conducts periodic reviews to monitor execution of the 'Supplier Performance Management Plan' .  During  each  review,  relevant  stakeholders provide updated status of respective actions.
- c. Any modifications made to the 'Supplier Performance Management Plan' are r eviewed and approved as per the PDoA .
- d. The 'Supplier Performance Management Plan' is completed when all high priority corrective actions are executed. Completion of 'Supplier Performance Management  Plan' is communicated to relevant stakeholders.

metadata.context: This chunk defines the R2P process group, outlining its key processes, scope, and stakeholders, and serves as a foundational overview for the subsequent detailed descriptions of individual processes like Create and Approve PR, Create and Approve PO, and Receive and Reconcile Invoice, as presented on pages 58 and beyond in the document.

nodes.text:
- a) The Requisition to Pay (R2P) process group consists of procedures for creation and approval of Purchase  Requisitions  (PR),  Purchase  Orders  (PO)  and  Goods/Services/Projects  Receipt.  It  also details the procedures for conducting Emergency, Petty Cash, and P-Card purchases and receiving goods/services/projects.
- b) This  section  explains  the  activities,  decisions  involved,  documents  used,  outcomes,  and  the stakeholders involved in the R2P processes.
- c) The following Level 3 processes are included in the R2P process group:
1. Create and Approve PR
2. Create and Approve PO
3. Receive Goods/Services/Projects
4. Conduct Emergency/Petty Cash/P-Card Purchase
5. Create and Approve Post Factum PR, PO, Goods/Services/Project Receipt
6. Receive and Reconcile Invoice

metadata.context: This chunk describes the process of creating and approving Purchase Orders (POs) from an approved Purchase Requisition (PR), including conditions under which Procurement involvement is optional (spend threshold below 50,000 AED with two quotations) or required (unknown supply source/conditions triggering a Sourcing Request). It is situated within the R2P process group, specifically under the "Create and Approve PO" activity on Page 58, linking PR approval to PO issuance and supplier confirmation.

nodes.text:
- i. The purpose of this process is to create, get relevant approvals and issue PO to the Supplier . The Supplier also confirms the receipt of the PO as a part of this process.
- ii. An approved PR leads directly to PO, if goods/services/projects requested in the PR are covered under an existing contract.
- iii. An approved PR may also lead directly to PO, if the spend threshold of goods/services/projects requested in the PR is below 50,000 AED. In such cases, involvement of Procurement is  not mandatory as long as the End-User has a minimum of 2 quotations.
- iv. In case the source of supply or conditions of purchase for the requested goods/services/projects are not known, 'Sourcing Request' is created by the Procurement for execution of Sourcing.

metadata.context: This Important Note appears in the "Create and Approve PR" section (Page 58) of the R2P process group, explaining that Procurement verifies an approved PR against existing contracts to determine if the requirement can be met without creating new obligations.

nodes.text: Important Note: Approved PR is verified by the Procurement against existing contracts to identify if the requirement can be fulfilled without entering into new obligations.

metadata.context: This chunk describes the components of a Purchase Order (PO) and the conditions under which multiple Purchase Requisitions (PRs) can be consolidated or split into multiple POs, specifically within the "Create and Approve PO" process of the R2P process group on Page 58–59.

nodes.text:
- a. A  Purchase  Order  (PO)  includes  details  such  as  description,  quantity,  price,  discount, payment terms etc. required to fulfil the order.
- b. Multiple PR may either be consolidated into an aggregate PO or single PR may be split into multiple POs for the following reasons:

metadata.context: This chunk explains the conditions under which a PR can be converted into a PO, including supplier diversity, delivery locations, and contract coverage, and specifies that Procurement creates the PO. It appears on Page 59 within the "Create and Approve PO" process section, linking PR approval to PO creation based on procurement requirements.

nodes.text:
- b1. Same/Different Suppliers -Goods/services/projects requested in the PR are procured through one or multiple Suppliers.
- b2. Same/Different Ship to Address -Goods/services/projects requested in the PR are to be delivered across one or more locations.
- b3. Contracted vs Non-Contracted -  Goods/services/projects requested in the PR may be partially fulfilled through an existing contract.
- c. A PR may be converted into a PO directly, through an existing contract, or through sourcing and contracting processes. PO is created by the Procurement .

metadata.context: This chunk reinforces a key control rule in the PR-to-PO process, stating that splitting an approved PR into multiple POs to circumvent approval authorities is prohibited, aligning with the document's emphasis on compliance and governance throughout procurement. It appears in both the PR approval and PO creation sections, ensuring consistency across process stages.

nodes.text: Important Note: An approved PR is not to be split into multiple POs to bypass approval authorities.

nodes.text:
- d. Completed PO is approved by the approvers designated as per the PDoA .
- e. Approved PO is shared with the Supplier .

metadata.context: This chunk describes the receipt and acceptance process for goods/services/projects, including quality inspection and handling of returns, and is directly aligned with Table 2.6.3 on Page 60, which outlines roles and responsibilities in receiving deliveries and creating formal receipts.

nodes.text:
- i. The purpose of this process is to confirm acceptance of the goods/services/projects and create a receipt for the accepted delivery.
- ii. The process includes quality inspection and management of return of goods to the Suppliers .

metadata.context: This chunk describes the reception and verification process of goods/services/projects against the PO, detailing acceptance or rejection criteria and responsibilities, and is located in the section on receiving deliveries (Page 60) following the creation and approval of POs.

nodes.text:
- i. Receive goods/services/projects and match against PO
- a. The goods received by the End-User or the store/warehouse are reviewed to ensure that the quantity delivered and specifications match with the PO and the delivery documents.
- b. Based on the review, one of the following approaches may be taken:

metadata.context: This chunk describes the acceptance criterion for goods delivery when quantity and specifications match the PO or are within specified tolerances, as outlined in the "Receive Goods/Services/Projects" process on Page 60. It is part of the decision-making framework for accepting or rejecting deliveries and aligns with the responsibilities of End-User or store/warehouse in verifying PO compliance.

nodes.text: - I. Delivery of goods is accepted by the End-User or store/warehouse if the quantity and  specification  match  with  that  provided  in  the  PO  or  are  within  acceptable tolerances specified in the PO.

metadata.context: This chunk describes the handling of rejected goods deliveries, including communication of discrepancies to Procurement and the Supplier, and the Supplier's obligation to replace defective or damaged goods or deliver missing items, as part of the goods receipt and acceptance process outlined in Table 2.6.3 on Page 60.

nodes.text:
- II. Delivery of goods can be rejected completely or partially (e.g., % of goods delivered are not as per the specification in the PO). In case of partial or complete rejection, the discrepancy is communicated to the Procurement and the Supplier.
- III. Depending on the reason for rejection, the Supplier either replaces the defective/damaged goods or delivers the missing goods.

metadata.context: This chunk describes the acceptance and rejection criteria for service/project deliveries in the Goods/Services/Projects Receipt process (Table 2.6.3), specifically on Page 60, where it outlines how end-users evaluate service compliance with PO specifications and handle discrepancies.

headings: ii. Create and approve Goods/Service/Projects Receipt

nodes.text:
- I. Delivery of services/projects is accepted by the End-User if the specification match with that provided in the PO or are within acceptable tolerances specified in the PO. The End-User provides  inputs  on  delivery  with  respect  to milestones,  KPI's/SLA, timelines etc.
- II. Delivery of services/projects can be rejected completely or partially. In case of partial or complete rejection, the discrepancy is communicated to the Procurement and the Supplier.

headings: ii. Create and approve Goods/Service/Projects Receipt
metadata.context: This chunk describes the responsibilities and process for creating, approving, and utilizing the Goods/Service/Projects Receipt during the receipt of delivered goods/services/projects, as outlined in Table 2.6.3 on Page 60, which follows the receipt and acceptance process after delivery matching against the PO.

nodes.text:
- a. End-User creates  Goods/Service/Projects  Receipt  reflecting  the  goods/services/projects accepted upon delivery or post inspection.
- b. In case of goods/services/projects with high value (as defined in the PDoA) the Entity may choose to form a committee to conduct the inspection.
- c. The  Goods/Service/Projects  Receipt  is  approved  by  the  approvers  designated as  per  the PDoA .
- d. The Goods/Service/Projects Receipt and PO are used as reference documents for invoice reconciliation process and authorizing payment to the Supplier .

metadata.context: This chunk describes the purpose, guidelines, and scope of expedited purchases (emergency and petty cash/P-Card) as outlined in the procurement process, specifically on Page 61 and referenced in Table 2.6.4 on Page 62, linking to emergency and low-threshold purchases authorized under the PDoA.

nodes.text:
- i. The purpose of this process is to enable expedited purchases in case of operational or personal emergencies as defined in the Procurement Standards.
- ii. The Procurement must ensure that emergency purchase is not used as an excuse for failing to plan.
- iii. This process also enables Petty Cash/P-Card purchases below certain spend thresholds specified in  the  PDoA .  Petty  Cash/P-Card  purchases  can  be  fulfilled  without  the  involvement  of  the Procurement .

metadata.context: This chunk describes the process for emergency purchases, detailing the end-user's initiation of a purchase request (PR) with justification, approval by designated approvers, procurement of the PO, and engagement with the supplier—aligned with the emergency purchase process outlined on Page 61 and referenced in Table 2.6.4 on Page 62.

nodes.text:
- a. Emergency purchase implies an expedited purchase above the spend threshold specified for P-Card or Petty Cash purchases in the PDoA .
- b. The End-User creates the PR and provides a justification for the emergency purchase.
- c. The PR and justification for emergency purchase is approved by approvers designated as per the PDoA .
- d. Procurement creates the PO which is approved by approvers designated as per the PDoA .
- e. Procurement engages with the Supplier and procures the required goods/services/projects.

metadata.context: This chunk describes the process for Petty Cash/P-Card purchases below spend thresholds, where the End-User directly engages the Supplier and PR/PO are created and approved post-factum, as outlined in Section 2.6.2.(IV) on Page 62.

nodes.text:
- a) For purchases below the spend threshold specified for P-Card or Petty Cash purchases in the PDoA, the End-user directly engages with the Supplier and procures required goods/services/projects.
- b) PR and PO are created and approved post-factum.

metadata.context: This chunk outlines the step-by-step responsibilities and actions for conducting emergency and petty cash/P-Card purchases, as detailed in Table 2.6.4 on Page 62 and aligned with the process map in Appendix 3.1-2.6.2.(IV). It specifies roles for end-users, procurement, and approvers in creating, justifying, and approving emergency purchases and petty cash/P-Card procurements, ensuring compliance with procurement standards and spend thresholds.

nodes.text: 1. In case of Emergency purchase, a) Create PR and provide justification for emergency purchase. b) Complete/update and submit justification for the emergency purchase. 2. In case of Petty Cash/P-Card purchase, a) Engage with the Supplier and procure required goods/services., Responsibilities = End-User. 3. Coordinate with End-User and store/warehouse to fulfill requirement, if possible. 4. Create PO and engage Supplier (in case of Emergency purchase). 5. Procure requested goods/services / projects., Responsibilities = Procurement. 6. Approve/deny PR and justification for the emergency purchase. 7. Approve/deny PO., Responsibilities = Approvers (as per PDoA)

metadata.context: This chunk introduces the Risk and Regulation (R&R) process group, which manages procurement risks and regulatory changes, particularly focusing on supplier, supply chain, and organizational risks, and is contextualized within the broader procurement process framework on pages 63–64.

nodes.text:
- a) The Risk and Regulation (R&R) process group consists of procedures for identification of high-risk Suppliers , and management of procurement risks and regulatory changes.
- b) This  section  explains  the  activities,  decisions  involved,  documents  used,  outcomes,  and  the stakeholders involved in the R&R processes.
- c) Procurement risk is defined as a potential for failure of any of the procurement processes. They may be associated with Supplier , supply chain, and procurement organization as following:

metadata.context: This chunk defines Supplier Risk and Supply Chain Risk within the Risk and Regulation (R&R) process group, as outlined in Section 2.6.2.(I) of the document, which discusses procurement risks associated with suppliers and external market events. It appears on page 64, in the context of risk identification and management in procurement.

nodes.text: Supplier Risk, Description = Risks emerging from Suppliers ' end and are specific to Supplier (e.g., bankruptcies, location change, price increase, quality/delivery failure, mergers and acquisitions etc.). Supply Chain Risk, Description = Risks emerging from unexpected external market events (e.g., environmental disasters causing supply chain disruption, price and supply volatility, supply shock, etc.)

metadata.context: This chunk defines Organizational Risk within the R&R process group, specifying that it arises from internal processes or organizational weaknesses such as poor market strategy, lack of procurement resources, or missing category expertise, and is part of the broader procurement risk classification alongside Supplier and Supply Chain risks.

nodes.text: Organizational Risk, Description = Risks emerging from internal processes/organization (e.g., incorrect approach to market, insufficient procurement resources, absence of category expertise, etc.)

nodes.text:
- d) The following Level 3 processes are included in the R&R process group:
1. Conduct Supplier Risk Profiling
2. Manage Procurement Risks
3. Manage Regulation Change

metadata.context: This chunk describes the Supplier Risk Profiling process within the Risk and Regulation (R&R) process group, outlining its purpose, frequency, responsible roles, and scope of application as part of procurement risk management. It is situated on Page 65 of the document, following an introduction to procurement risks and preceding the detailed activities and risk assessment criteria. This context helps search systems associate the chunk with risk identification, supplier categorization, and organizational risk management procedures.

headings: Table 2.7.1 Roles and Responsibilities -Sources of procurement risks

nodes.text:
- i. The purpose of this process is to identify high risk Suppliers and optimize the risk mitigation efforts.
- ii. Conduct Supplier Risk Profiling process is conducted periodically, preferably once a year.
- iii. An SRM Specialist is assigned to conduct risk profiling for Suppliers . To conduct risk profiling of Suppliers catering to Entity-Specific Categories, the SRM Specialist is assigned from the Entity. . To  conduct  risk  profiling  of Suppliers catering  to  Common  Categories,  the SRM Specialist is assigned from the GPO.
- iv. As per the Supplier Segment Strategy (please refer to Figure 2.5.2 ), the risk profiling is conducted for following Suppliers :
- a. All Strategic and Critical Suppliers.
- b. Operational Suppliers with spend in the top 80% of the Entity spend.

metadata.context: This chunk describes the methodology for conducting Supplier Risk Profiling, including the use of a structured input form to evaluate suppliers across financial, operational, environmental, and legislative risks, and the criteria for identifying high-risk suppliers based on a four-point risk scoring system. It is situated within the R&R process group on Page 65, under the "Conduct Supplier Risk Profiling" activity.

nodes.text:
- i. Complete 'Supplier Risk Profiling Report'
- a. 'Supplier Risk Profiling Input Collection Form' template is designed to assess following types of Supplier risks:
3. a1. Financial Risk
4. a2. Operational Risk
5. a3. Environmental Risk
6. a4. Legislative Risk
- b. Suppliers are evaluated on above mentioned risk types on a four-point scale (0 -No risk, 1 -Low Risk, 2- Medium risk, 3 -High risk, and 4 -Significant risk). Suppliers with a score of 3 (or above) on any of the risk types are considered as high-risk Suppliers .

metadata.context: This chunk describes the process flow for conducting Supplier Risk Profiling, including how the SRM Specialist collects risk inputs from Category Managers or End-Users/Contract Administrators, consolidates the data, identifies high-risk suppliers, and ensures a single consolidated report is shared with stakeholders—aligning with the procedures detailed on Page 65 and 66.

nodes.text:
- c. The assigned SRM Specialist shares the 'Supplier Risk Input Collection Form ' with Category Managers to collate risk scores for Suppliers specific to their category.
- d. In case of categories without assigned Category Managers, 'Supplier Risk Input C ollection Form' is shared with Contract Administrators or End-Users .
- e. The assigned SRM Specialist collates various 'Supplier Risk Input Collection Form', completes the 'Supplier Risk Profiling Report' template, and identifies high risk Suppliers .
- f. There can only be one 'Supplier Risk Profiling Report' for an Entity/GPO which is shared with the relevant stakeholders.

metadata.context: This chunk outlines the specific responsibilities of SRM Specialists and Category Managers/End-Users/Contract Administrators in the Supplier Risk Profiling process, as detailed on Page 66 within the broader context of identifying and managing supplier risks. It defines the workflow for collecting, collating, and sharing supplier risk data to identify high-risk suppliers, supporting the risk mitigation efforts described in the R&R process group.

headings: Table 2.7.2 Roles and Responsibilities -Conduct Supplier Risk Profiling

nodes.text: SRM Specialist, Responsibilities = 1. Share 'Supplier Risk Profiling Input Collection Form' with Category Managers/ End-Users/ Contract Administrators . 2. - b. AD-DED Suppliers raise  a 'Supplier Self -Registration Request' by opening the 'SAP Ariba Supplier SelfRegistration Request link' and completing and submitting the 'Self -Registration Request form'.

nodes.text: - i. The purpose of this process is to qualify/disqualify a Supplier . Supplier must be 'Qualified' to be awarded or for issuance of PO.

metadata.context: This chunk describes the qualification process for suppliers, as outlined in Table 2.8.4 on Page 79, where the Supplier Manager initiates the qualification by completing and sending the Qualification Questionnaire, which includes declarations on business, financial, and experience standing, followed by review and approval by the Supplier Manager and Supplier Data Management Lead, resulting in the supplier's status being marked as "Qualified" and enabling awarding of purchase orders.

nodes.text:
- a. The 'Supplier Manager' completes the 'Pre -Qualification Questionnaire' and specifies the category, region and entity for which the Supplier is to be 'Qualified'.
- b. The  'Supplier  Manager'  sends  the  'Qualification  Questionnaire'  to  the Supplier .  The 'Qualification Questionnaire' contains sections for the Supplier to provide declarations with respect to business standing, financial standing, and previous experience.
- c. The Supplier receives and responds to all sections in the 'Qualification Questionnaire'.
- d. The res ponses to 'Qualification Questionnaire' are reviewed by the 'Supplier Manager' and, subsequently, the Supplier Data Management Lead .
- e. The Supplier status changes to 'Qualified' (automatically) once the 'Qualification Questionnaire' is 'Approved' by the Supplier Data Management Lead.
- f. Suppliers can be awarded and conduct business for categories for which they are 'Qualified' .

- d. When the 'Disqualification Expiry Date' has passed, the 'Supplier Manager' may re -initiate the qualification process for the Supplier, as explained above.

- a. The 'Preferred' status of the Supplier depends on meeting the following criteria:
3. a1. The Supplier's 'Performance Score' must be > 85% and;
4. a2. The Supplier should either be a Common Category Supplier or in the top 80% spend of an Entity-Specific Category spend
- b. Suppliers  categorized  as  MSME,  Start-up,  Emirati  Entrepreneurs  or  Freelancers  (refer  to Section 1.5 ) are marked 'Preferred' for the respective categories.
- c. A 'Preferred' Supplier appears on top of the search list for the respective category, when creating a Sourcing Event.

metadata.context: This chunk describes the purpose of the deactivation and reactivation process for suppliers with expired commercial/industrial licenses, as outlined in Table 2.8.6 on Page 80, which details the roles and responsibilities involved in managing such supplier status changes.

nodes.text: - i. The purpose of this process is to deactivate Suppliers with an expired commercial/industrial license and reactivate them once the commercial/industrial License is renewed.

metadata.context: This chunk describes the process for deactivating suppliers with expired commercial/industrial licenses, including the conditions, responsibilities, and actions taken by the Supplier Data Management Specialist and Supplier Manager, as outlined in Table 2.8.6 on Page 80.

nodes.text:
- a. 'Deactivated' status implies that the 'SAP Ariba' profile of the Supplier is no longer active. Suppliers  in  'Deactivated'  status  are  not  visible  in  any  search  list,  cannot  participate  in tenders, and cannot be awarded.
- b. All existing contracts with the Supplier must be terminated before deactivating a Supplier .
- c. A Supplier Data Management Specialist is  assigned  to  conduct  quarterly  reviews  of  the Supplier Master Database and identify Suppliers with expired commercial/industrial license .
- d. The Suppliers with  expired  commercial/industrial  license  receive  an  email  requesting  to renew the license. The email mentions that if the renewed license is not reflected in 'SAP Ariba' before the next quarterly review, the Supplier may be 'Deactivated'.
- e. In  case  the  assigned Supplier  Data  Management Specialist identifies  a Supplier with  an expired  commercial/industrial  license  in  the  next  quarterly  review  as  well  (even  after reminder),  the 'Supplier  Manager' may  'Deactivate'  t he Supplier and  provide  a  valid justification for the same.

metadata.context: This chunk describes the steps a supplier must take to renew their commercial/industrial license and be reactivated in SAP Ariba, following deactivation due to an expired license. It aligns with the deactivation/reactivation process detailed in Table 2.8.6 on Page 81, specifically under the responsibilities of the supplier and supplier manager.

nodes.text:
- a. Supplier  must  update  the  'Registration  Questionnaire'  with  the  renewed  Commercial/ industrial license information to continue business. This is done through the Update Supplier Registration process explained in S ection 2.8.2.(III) .
- b. Upon review of the renewed commercial/industrial license, the 'Supplier Manager' may 'Reactivate' the Supplier. A reactivated Supplier resumes the same status as it had before deactivation.

metadata.context: This chunk describes the Item Master Data Management (Item MDM) process group, which, although not directly detailed in the provided supplier-related sections, complements the supplier data management framework by outlining the centralized maintenance of item records for goods, services, and projects—ensuring data accuracy and consistency across procurement processes. It should be situated alongside supplier data processes (e.g., registration, deactivation/reactivation) as part of the broader master data management framework.

nodes.text:
- a) Item Master Data Management (Item MDM) process group consists of procedures associated with the creation and maintenance of records of items representing unique goods/services/projects.
- b) The Item Master Data provides accurate, consistent and complete record of goods/services/ projects procured.
- c) The responsibility for maintaining Item Master Data is centralized.

metadata.context: This chunk outlines the guidelines and processes for creating and maintaining Item Master Data, including record criteria, UNSPSC classification, data integrity practices, and the key Level 3 process of adding, modifying, or deleting item records, as detailed in the Item MDM process group on pages 82–83.

nodes.text:
- d) Following guidelines must be adhered to during creation and maintenance of the Item Master Database:
1. Records of Item Master Data are created for frequently purchased goods/services/projects.
2. Each item is identified by a unique code in the Item Master Data.
3. The record of each item contains (but not limited to):
- i. Item Code
- ii. Description
- iii. Item type
- iv. Item group
- v. Unit of Measurement
- vi. Unit Price
4. Each item belong s to one of the UNSPSC Level 3 'Classes'. UNSPSC classification is explained in section 1.2.2.
5. Item Master Database is regularly cleansed to identify and remove duplicate records and rectify incomplete and inconsistent records, to ensure data integrity.
6. The following Level 3 processes is included in the Item MDM process group:
1. Add/modify/delete Item record

nodes.text:
- a) User Master Data Management (User MDM) process group consists of procedures associated with the  creation  and  maintenance  of  records  of  individuals  involved  in  procurement  activities including.
- b) User Master Data provides accurate, consistent and complete record of procurement practitioners.
- c) The responsibility for maintaining User Master Data is centralized.
- d) Following guidelines must be adhered to during creation and maintenance of the  User Master Database:
1. Records of User Master Data are created for all procurement practitioners.
2. Each User is identified by a User ID in the User Master Data.
3. The record of each user contains (but not limited to):
- i. User ID
- ii. Name
- iii. Designation
- iv. Entity
- v. Contact Details
- vi. Function
- vii. Role and Authorizations
4. User Master Database is regularly cleansed to identify and remove duplicate records and rectify incomplete and inconsistent records, to ensure data integrity.
5. The following Level 3 processes is included in the User MDM process group:
- i. Add/modify/delete User record

metadata.context: This chunk provides definitions of key terms used in the procurement process, as defined on Page 117 of the manual. It supplements the abbreviations list on Page 116 by offering clear, concise explanations for critical roles, processes, and concepts such as Bank Information Specialist, Baseline Spend, Bid Bond, Budget Owner, Catalogue, Common Category, End-User, Entity, Entity-Specific Category, Finance, Goods/Services/Projects Receipt, GPO Approver, Head of Procurement, Legal, Limited Tender, P-Card, Performance Bond, Petty Cash, Procurement, Procurement Benefits, Procurement Charter, and Procurement Delegation of Authority (PDoA). These definitions are essential for understanding procurement workflows, responsibilities, and governance structures.

nodes.text: Bank Information Specialist, Definition / Description = A system role assigned for validating the information provided in the 'Payment and Bank Questionnaire'.. Baseline Spend, Definition / Description = Addressable spend against which any benefit is measured.. Bid Bond, Definition / Description = A bank guarantee submitted with bids to assure serious participation in the tender.. Budget Owner, Definition / Description = A business role accountable for spending decisions of the section/department.. Catalogue, Definition / Description = A database of goods/services/projects readily available for raising a PR.. Common Category, Definition / Description = Category procured by five or more Entities.. End-User, Definition / Description = The requesters or requesting parties of goods, services and projects.. Entity, Definition / Description = Local departments and every juridical person reporting to the Government and having full legal capacity to act and manage a public facility or aiming to provide a public service.. Entity-Specific Category, Definition / Description = Category procured by less than five Entities. Finance, Definition / Description = The function within the government entity dedicated to financial affairs.. Goods/Services/Projects Receipt, Definition / Description = A document issued to acknowledge the receipt of goods/services/projects.. GPO Approver, Definition / Description = Designated approvers from the GPO.. Head of Procurement, Definition / Description = Individual assigned to lead the procurement unit.. Legal, Definition / Description = The function within the government entity dedicated to legal affairs.. Limited Tender, Definition / Description = A tendering method that is open to predefined number of registered Suppliers.. P-Card, Definition / Description = Corporate card issued to authorized employees for making electronic payments for goods/service/projects.. Performance Bond, Definition / Description = A bank guarantee provided by the supplier or contractor to secure good performance and compliance with of the contract terms and conditions.. Petty Cash, Definition / Description = Small amounts of discretionary funds in the form of cash (defined in the PDoA) used for expenditures.. Procurement, Definition / Description = The procurement function existing within or outside the government entity.. Procurement Benefits, Definition / Description = Benefits that result in Cost Reduction, Cost Avoidance, and Cash Impact for procurement.. Procurement Charter, Definition / Description = A formal document defining the roles and committees required for the procurement operations.. Procurement Delegation of Authority (PDoA), Definition / Description = A formal document defining division of authority and powers in the government entity related to procurement operations.

metadata.context: This chunk expands on definitions found on Page 118, providing detailed descriptions of key procurement terms such as Procurement Framework, Procurement Standards, Public Tender, Purchase Order, Purchase Requisition, RFI, RFP, RFQ, Requestor, Reverse Auction, Service Completion Certificate, Sole/Single Source, Sourcing Request, Supplier, Supplier Manager, and Tendering Committee, building upon the foundational definitions introduced in the document.

nodes.text: Procurement Framework, Definition / Description = A set of interrelated documents devised to help procurement professionals in their work.. Procurement Standards, Definition / Description = An integrated set of principles that harmonize the way of working, establish a unified operating model and define the performance of the Procurement.. Public Tender, Definition / Description = A tendering method that is open to all Suppliers, and where the bids are invited through public announcements.. Purchase Order, Definition / Description = A legally binding document issued by the government entity to Suppliers in reference to the Contract or the Price List Agreement or on a standalone basis, indicating key parameters of purchase such as quantities, agreed prices, delivery schedule, payment terms and other relevant information and committing both parties upon explicit or implicit confirmation by Supplier.. Purchase Requisition, Definition / Description = A request generated by an End-User for securing goods/services/projects.. Request for Information (RFI), Definition / Description = Sourcing Event used for screening Suppliers and gathering information or budget estimates from a broad base of potential Suppliers.. Request for Proposal (RFP), Definition / Description = Sourcing Event used for seeking technical and commercial proposals from Suppliers.. Request for Quotation (RFQ), Definition / Description = Sourcing Event used for seeking pricing information for a defined scope of work or supply of specified goods or services.. Requestor, Definition / Description = Any government employee raising a request for goods/services/projects or other services provided by the GPO.. Reverse Auction (eAuction), Definition / Description = Sourcing Event used for seeking competitive bids in real time for highly commoditized goods, services and projects where specifications have already been fully acknowledged by participating Suppliers.. Service Completion Certificate, Definition / Description = A document issued to acknowledge the completion of a service.. Sole/Single Source, Definition / Description = A tendering method that is open to only one qualified Supplier capable of supplying the required goods, services and projects or a single Supplier is selected from a pool of qualified Suppliers.. Sourcing Request, Definition / Description = A request to find the supply source for the required goods/services/projects.. Supplier, Definition / Description = An individual or an organization engaged to supply the goods/services/projects.. "Supplier Manager", Definition / Description = A system role assigned for registering and qualifying Suppliers.. Tendering Committee, Definition / Description = A committee established to evaluate the results of relevant tenders and encourage cross-functional collaboration.
